abstract.p: DDB Worldwide's Chicago office wins top honor in television and cinema category at International Advertising Festival, Cannes, France; Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide's London office wins top honor in print and poster category (M)

block.p: Two campaigns for beer brands took top honors at the 47th annual International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France, winning the Grand Prix awards in the categories of television and cinema advertising as well as print and poster advertising.

The popular ''Whassup'' campaign for Budweiser beer by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, won in the television and cinema category in a decision announced on Saturday. The campaign from Anheuser-Busch was composed of five commercials centered on a group of friends who repeat the greeting ''Whassup'' in a variety of fanciful intonations.

Two campaigns for beer brands took top honors at the 47th annual International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France, winning the Grand Prix awards in the categories of television and cinema advertising as well as print and poster advertising.

The popular ''Whassup'' campaign for Budweiser beer by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, won in the television and cinema category in a decision announced on Saturday. The campaign from Anheuser-Busch was composed of five commercials centered on a group of friends who repeat the greeting ''Whassup'' in a variety of fanciful intonations.

In the television and cinema category, of 25 gold awards called Lions, American agencies won 10. Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., won four for work for AltaVista, Nike and Stamps.com. Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York and the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, owned by Publicis S.A., each won two.

In the print and poster category, the London office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, won for British ads for Stella Artois beer, licensed by the Whitbread Beer Company. The humorous ads show valuable objects like Charles Eames chairs that were damaged after being used as bottle openers.

Of the 29 gold Lions in the print and poster category, British agencies won the most, 8, followed by French agencies, with 6; American agencies won 2, for a Sports Illustrated campaign by the Minneapolis office of Fallon and a pro bono campaign for the Virginia Holocaust Museum by the Martin Agency in Richmond, part of the Lowe Group unit of Interpublic.

In the interactive competition, known as Cyber Lions, an American agency won one gold Lion, ZeniMax Media in Rockville, Md., for work for Vir2L Technology. Two Grand Prix Awards were presented, to AgenciaClick in Sao Paulo, Brazil and Framfab in Copenhagen.
